articles.author: Dustin Childs
articles.description:
It‚Äôs the spooky season, and there‚Äôs nothing spookier than security patches ‚Äì at least in my world. Microsoft and Adobe have released their latest patches, and no bones about it, there are some skeletons in those closets. Take a break from your regular activities and join us as we review the details of their latest security alerts. If you‚Äôd rather watch the full video recap covering the entire release, you can check it out here:
Adobe Patches for October 2024
For October, Adobe released nine patches addressing 52 CVEs in Adobe Substance 3D Painter, Commerce, Dimension, Animate, Lightroom, InCopy, InDesign, Substance 3D Stager, and Adobe FrameMaker. Two of these bugs were submitted through the ZDI program. The largest and most urgent of these patches covers 22 CVEs in Adobe Commerce, which i‚Ä¶
articles.title: The October 2024 Security Update Review

articles.author: Connor Ford
articles.description:
This blog post highlights two additional¬†vulnerabilities in the Autel Maxicharger that were exploited at Pwn2Own Automotive 2024. Details of the patches are also included.
Autel has been informed and has deployed a firmware update (v1.35) to address both of these issues. If you want to read about other Autel bugs reported at Pwn2Own, you check out our earlier blog here.
The First Vulnerability: CVE-2024-23967 (ZDI-CAN-23230)
Researchers from Computest Sector 7 identified and exploited a stack-based buffer overflow in v1.32 of the Autel firmware. This vulnerability stems from the decoding of base64 encoded data that can be controlled by an attacker. The encoded data is decoded into a fixed-size stack buffer with no bounds checks, leading to a stack buffer overflow and remote code execution.‚Ä¶
articles.title: From Pwn2Own Automotive: More Autel Maxicharger Vulnerabilities

articles.author: Piotr Bazyd≈Ço
articles.description:
As you may know, I recently presented my Exchange-related talk during OffensiveCon 2024. This series of 4 blog posts is meant to supplement the talk and provide additional technical details.
In this final part, I ‚Äôam going to describe the PowerShell Remoting ConvertViaNoArgumentConstructor conversion mechanism, which I underestimated at the beginning of my research. It allowed me to find 3 more vulnerabilities, even after the Exchange PowerShell attack surface had been significantly hardened by switching to a strict allow list of types. The vulnerabilities I found were:  
‚Ä¢	CVE-2023-36050 ‚Äì XXE (File Read)
‚Ä¢	CVE-2023-36039 ‚Äì NTLM Relaying
‚Ä¢	CVE-2023-36035 ‚Äì NTLM Relaying  
At least at that time, Microsoft was taking seriously NTLM relaying vulnerabilities in Exchange, because it could lead‚Ä¶
articles.title: Exploiting Exchange PowerShell After ProxyNotShell: Part 4 ‚Äì No Argument Constructor

articles.author: Dustin Childs
articles.description:
If you just want to read the rules, you can find them here.
Earlier this year we held our inaugural Pwn2Own Automotive contest, and it was a rousing success. On our biggest-ever stage (literally), we awarded $1,323,750 over the three-day event as researchers from around the globe demonstrated 49 unique zero days. Today, we‚Äôre excited to announce that we will be returning to Tokyo and the Automotive World conference for Pwn2Own Automotive 2025. The event will be held on January 22-24, 2025, and we have some exciting challenges planned for our second year.
As always, we‚Äôre pleased to be working with our cohorts over at VicOne again. Their help was instrumental in the success we had at our first event, and we‚Äôre glad to be partnering with them once more. Tesla also returns as a sponsor. They ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Announcing Pwn2Own Automotive for 2025

articles.author: Piotr Bazyd≈Ço
articles.description:
As you may know, I recently presented my Exchange-related talk during OffensiveCon 2024. This series of 4 blog posts is meant to supplement the talk and provide additional technical details. 
In this article, part 3 of the series, I describe a chain of 3 vulnerabilities that led to remote code execution:
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† CVE-2023-36744 ‚Äì Arbitrary File Write vulnerability
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† CVE-2023-36777 ‚Äì Arbitrary File Read vulnerability
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† CVE-2023-36745 ‚Äì Local DLL Loading vulnerability
In the sections that follow, I‚Äôm going to describe each of these in detail and show how I chained them to eventually achieve RCE.
You can also watch the talk here: ‚ÄúHalf Measures and Full Compromise: Exploiting Microsoft Exchange PowerShell Remoting‚Äù. This blog post covers the part from 21:00 to 26:25.
Introduction
I‚Ä¶
articles.title: Exploiting Exchange PowerShell After ProxyNotShell: Part 3 ‚Äì DLL Loading Chain for RCE

articles.author: Piotr Bazyd≈Ço
articles.description:
As you may know, I recently presented my Exchange-related talk during OffensiveCon 2024. This series of 4 blog posts is meant to supplement the talk and provide additional technical details. You can read the first post in this series here.
In part 2, I describe the ApprovedApplicationCollection gadget, which was available for abuse because it did not appear on the deny list and could therefore be accessed via MultiValuedProperty. I am also presenting a path traversal in the Windows utility extrac32.exe, which allowed me to complete the chain for a full RCE in Exchange. For the moment, at least, Microsoft has made a decision not to fix this path traversal bug.
You can watch the full talk here: ‚ÄúHalf Measures and Full Compromise: Exploiting Microsoft Exchange PowerShell Remoting‚Äù. This blog ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Exploiting Exchange PowerShell After ProxyNotShell: Part 2 - ApprovedApplicationCollection

articles.author: Dustin Childs
articles.description:
We‚Äôve reached September and the pumpkin spice floats in the air. While they aren‚Äôt pumpkin-spiced, Microsoft and Adobe have released their latest spicy security patches ‚Äì including some zesty 0-days. Take a break from your regular activities and join us as we review the details of their latest security alerts.If you‚Äôd rather watch the full video recap covering the entire release, you can check it out here:
Adobe Patches for September 2024
For September, Adobe released eight bulletins covering 28 CVEs in Adobe Acrobat and Reader, ColdFusion, Photoshop, Media Encoder, Audition, After Effects, Premier Pro, and Illustrator. A total of seven of these bugs came through the ZDI program. If you‚Äôre prioritizing, I would look at the ColdFusion patch first. It corrects a single code execution bug rat‚Ä¶
articles.title: The September 2024 Security Update Review

(https://www.nccgroup.com/us/research-blog/feed/) Be sure to [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: New website address and RSS Feed

articles.title: CloudGoat Official Walkthrough Series: ‚Äòglue_privesc‚Äô

articles.description:
Introduction
In this post, we are going to explore a rarely discussed class of vulnerabilities in Ruby, known as class pollution. This concept is inspired by the idea of prototype pollution in JavaScript, where recursive merges are exploited to poison the prototype of objects, leading to unexpected behaviors. This idea was initially discussed in a blog post about prototype pollution in Python, in which the researcher used recursive merging to poison class variables and eventually global variables via the __globals__ attribute.
In Ruby, we can categorize class pollution into three main cases:
Merge on Hashes: In this scenario, class pollution isn‚Äôt possible because the merge operation is confined to the hash itself.
Merge on Attributes (Non-Recursive): Here, we can poison the instance varia‚Ä¶
articles.title: Class Pollution in Ruby: A Deep Dive into Exploiting Recursive Merges

articles.description:
Introduction
Recently Doyensec was hired by a client offering a ‚ÄúCommunication Platform as a Service‚Äù. This platform allows their clients to craft a customer service experience and to communicate with their own customers via a plethora of channels: email, web chats, social media and more.
While undoubtedly valuable, such a service introduces a unique threat model. Our client‚Äôs users work with a vast amount of incoming correspondence from outside (often anonymous) users, on a daily basis. This makes them particularly vulnerable to phishing and other social engineering attacks.
While such threats cannot be fully eliminated, it is possible to minimize the possibilities for exploitation. Recognizing this, Doyensec was hired to performed a security review, specifically focused on social enginee‚Ä¶
articles.title: Applying Security Engineering to Make Phishing Harder - A Case Study

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Cliff Smith Software supply chain security has been a hot topic since the Solarwinds breach back in 2020. Thanks to the Supply-chain Levels for Software Artifacts (SLSA) framework, the software industry is now at the threshold of sustainably solving many of the biggest challenges in securely building and distributing open-source software. SLSA is a [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Securing the software supply chain with the SLSA framework

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Pawe≈Ç P≈Çatek In the race to secure cloud applications, AWS Nitro Enclaves have emerged as a powerful tool for isolating sensitive workloads. But with great power comes great responsibility‚Äîand potential security pitfalls. As pioneers in confidential computing security, we at Trail of Bits have scrutinized the attack surface of AWS Nitro Enclaves, uncovering potential [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: A few notes on AWS Nitro Enclaves: Attack surface

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: At Trail of Bits, we aim to share and develop tools and resources used in our security assessments with the broader security community. Many clients, we observed, don‚Äôt use Semgrep to its fullest potential or even at all. To bridge this gap and encourage broader adoption, our CEO, Dan Guido, initiated discussions with the Semgrep [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Announcing the Trail of Bits and Semgrep partnership

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: At DEF CON, Michael Brown, Principal Security Engineer at Trail of Bits, sat down with Michael Novinson from Information Security Media Group (ISMG) to discuss four critical areas where AI/ML is revolutionizing security. Here‚Äôs what they covered: AI/ML techniques surpass the limits of traditional software analysis As Moore‚Äôs law slows down after 20 years of [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Inside DEF CON: Michael Brown on how AI/ML is revolutionizing cybersecurity

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Joe Doyle If you‚Äôve encountered cryptography software, you‚Äôve probably heard the advice to never use a nonce twice‚Äîin fact, that‚Äôs where the word nonce (number used once) comes from. Depending on the cryptography involved, a reused nonce can reveal encrypted messages, or even leak your secret key! But common knowledge may not cover every [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Friends don‚Äôt let friends reuse nonces

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Dominik Klemba and Dominik Czarnota AddressSanitizer (ASan) is a compiler plugin that helps detect memory errors like buffer overflows or use-after-frees. In this post, we explain how to equip your C++ code with ASan annotations to find more bugs. We also show our work on ASan in GCC and LLVM. In LLVM, Trail of [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Sanitize your C++ containers: ASan annotations step-by-step

articles.author: Andy Gill
articles.description: This post explores Windows Side-by-Side (WinSxS) and DLL hijacking, deep-diving some tooling I've written and some of the fun along the way.
articles.title: Side-by-Side with HelloJackHunter: Unveiling the Mysteries of WinSxS

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description: Windows 11 24H2 introduces several Group Policy settings to manage its new features centrally. Windows Defender receives 26 new settings, and many focus on enhancing SMB security. The new settings also control reboots after updates and the transition to Windows Protected Print.
articles.title: Windows 11 24H2 Group Policy: 81 new settings for SMB, updates, printing, Defender, and more

articles.author: Amr Essam
articles.description: AWS has recently introduced support for conditional writes in S3 storage. This feature enables S3 to verify whether an object exists before creating it, which helps prevent accidental overwriting of existing objects during data uploads. This capability is particularly useful for distributed applications that simultaneously access and write data to S3. In this article, I will showcase how to use the newly introduced --if-none-match parameter.
articles.title: AWS S3 Conditional Writes: The ‚Äìif-none-match parameter

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description: Setting up management, compute, and storage networks in a Windows cluster can be challenging and error-prone. Network ATC automates this process. Available in Azure Stack HCI since version 21H2, it is now integrated into Windows Server 2025.
articles.title: Windows Server 2025 Network ATC: Automatically configure networks in a cluster using intends

articles.author: Thomas Joos
articles.description: OWASP ModSecurity is an open-source Web Application Firewall (WAF) that protects web servers from common attacks. ModSecurity inspects all incoming requests to prevent attacks such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), SQL Injection, or Remote Code Execution. The software supports Apache, Nginx, and IIS on Windows Server. This guide demonstrates how to set up the firewall on a Windows Server 2025. You'll need to use version 2.9.7 since newer versions (3.x and above) are not yet available for Windows.
articles.title: OWASP ModSecurity: Web Application Firewall (WAF) for IIS

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description: Alongside the revamped Start Menu, one of the most noticeable changes in Windows 11 is the redesigned context menu in File Explorer. However, these modifications are not merely aesthetic ‚Äì they also restrict its functionality. You can deploy a registry key using Group Policy Preferences to restore the classic context.
articles.title: Restore classic context menu in Windows 11 Explorer using Group Policy or PowerShell

articles.author: Leos Marek
articles.description: The latest PowerToys update introduced Workspaces, enabling users to open a group of applications in predefined positions with just one click. This post will explain how to use the Workspaces feature and showcase its key features.
articles.title: Microsoft PowerToys Workspaces: Group Windows apps

articles.author: Edem Afenyo
articles.description: Windows 11 24H2, the yearly feature update, is now available for high-end AI-capable devices, with a broader rollout to other PCs in the next few weeks. This article explores the features introduced in the update.
articles.title: New in the Windows 11 24H2 update: Download and install, AI features, sudo for Windows, checkpoint updates, and more

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description: Microsoft provides two primary options for migrating to Windows Server 2025: performing a clean install (fresh install, wipe and load) or a feature update (in-place upgrade). Although the upgrade is quicker and less complicated, it is irreversible and comes with a risk of failure. Windows Server 2025 adopts the same upgrade strategy as Windows 11, with Microsoft's recommended method being an in-place update. Terms like feature update, upgrade, and in-place update are used interchangeably.
articles.title: Windows Server 2025 upgrade: Feature update versus clean install

articles.author: Amr Essam
articles.description: AWS has recently unveiled the open-source release of the Secrets Manager Agent. This local HTTP service is designed to be installed within various compute environments. Its purpose is to fetch secrets from Secrets Manager and cache them in memory for efficient application access. This approach offers a simplified and consistent method to consume secrets across diverse environments.
articles.title: How to install the AWS Secrets Manager Agent

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description: All browser vendors configure a default search engine that handles queries entered into the address bar. Microsoft provides Bing, Google uses its own search engine, and Mozilla partners with Google. The default search engines can be changed through Group Policy.
articles.title: Set the default search engine in Chrome, Edge, and Firefox with Group Policy

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description: Microsoft has officially announced Office LTSC 2024, the newest iteration of its Long-Term Servicing Channel (LTSC) suite. This article examines the new features in Office 2024, compares the standard to the LTSC edition, and breaks down their respective pricing models. Finally, I‚Äôll explain why Microsoft leverages the hefty LTSC price tag and the new AI feature to lure you toward a Microsoft 365 subscription.
articles.title: Microsoft Office 2024 (LTSC): new features, pricing, and the stability tax

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description: In a recent post, we discussed the new features in Docker Desktop 4.33. This post will cover what's new in Docker Desktop 4.34.
articles.title: New in Docker Desktop 4.34: MSI installer, host networking, auto disk space reclamation, NVIDIA AI workbench, Compose Bridge

articles.author: Nicki Borell
articles.description: Saving identical text as both a Word file and a PDF leads to different responses from Copilot because of the fragmented nature of PDF files. Here's why this occurs and how to modify your prompt for more consistent results.
articles.title: Different Copilot responses with identical PDF and DOCX content: Causes and solutions

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description: Changing the SSH port on Ubuntu 24.04 differs from that on Ubuntu 22.04 and older. Since Ubuntu 22.10, the SSH daemon (sshd) uses socket-based activation, which means that the traditional method of changing the port in /etc/ssh/sshd_config is no longer sufficient. In addition, you need to modify the socket configuration to specify the new port using the ListenStream directive.
articles.title: How to change the SSH port on Ubuntu 24.04

articles.author: Wolfgang Miedl
articles.description: Microsoft is maintaining a brisk pace with its AI strategy. Under the title "Microsoft Copilot Wave 2," Redmond unveiled a bundle of innovations and improvements surrounding the diverse Copilot portfolio. There are especially exciting updates in collaboration and Office integration.
articles.title: Microsoft 365 Copilot: Wave 2

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description: OpenAI has officially launched its long-awaited "reasoning" AI model, formerly referred to as "Strawberry" and Q* (Q-star), now named OpenAI o1. Launched as o1-preview and o1-mini, this new family of models promises to tackle complex problems more effectively than its predecessors, including GPT-4o. However, while initial reports are promising, key questions remain about its capabilities. What matters most to me is whether OpenAI resolves the hallucination problem, an issue that all large language models (LLMs) face.
articles.title: Does OpenAI‚Äôs new model o1 solve the hallucination problem?

articles.author: Brandon Lee
articles.description: Many IT admins manage both on-premises Active Directory environments and hybrid setups like Microsoft 365. Constantly switching between on-premises management and Microsoft 365 can be challenging. Easy365Manager aims to simplify this process. Let's explore this tool and the features it offers for hybrid management.
articles.title: Manage Microsoft 365 from Active Directory Users and Computers (ADUC) with Easy365Manager

articles.author: Nicki Borell
articles.description: When the knowledge of a language model is insufficient to answer questions, integrating additional data sources comprehensively can be beneficial. Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) serves this purpose by connecting to data sources outside the trained language model. Microsoft 365 Copilot already works with RAG and is now expanding with GraphRAG to unlock even more extensive knowledge.
articles.title: Expand the Copilot Language Model with external data sources using GraphRAG

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description: NVIDIA's quasi-monopoly in the AI GPU market is achieved through its CUDA platform's early development and widespread adoption. It serves as a moat by becoming the industry standard due to its superior performance and integration with key AI tools. While NVIDIA's dominance is bolstered by its proprietary advantages and developer lock-in, emerging competitors like AMD and innovations such as AMD's ROCm, OpenAI's Triton, and PyTorch 2.0 are beginning to challenge this stronghold by offering open-source alternatives and reducing reliance on CUDA.
articles.title: NVIDIA CUDA monopoly faces competition from AMD‚Äôs open-source alternative ROCm

articles.author: Wolfgang Miedl
articles.description: How secure is the data in Microsoft 365, and what basic measures does Microsoft offer for data protection and reliability? The company has integrated some safeguarding mechanisms to protect customers from data mishaps. There is also a new framework that outlines the responsibilities of both the provider and the customer. Here's an overview of tools and regulations.
articles.title: Built-in data security in Microsoft 365: What Microsoft provides and what the customer is responsible for

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description: VMware Workstation Pro 17.6 introduces a couple of valuable changes. Notably, it is now available for free for personal use. The update enhances OS support, adding compatibility with systems like Windows Server 2025 and Ubuntu 24.04 as both hosts and guests. Additionally, new tools like the vmcli command-line utility streamline virtual machine management, while crucial bug fixes and security updates enhance the platform's reliability and efficiency.
articles.title: VMware Workstation Pro 17.6: Free for personal use, enhanced OS support, and improved performance

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description: In my last post, I discussed three standard methods to block AI crawlers that have little prospect of being successful. Please also read it if you want to know why it is important to block AI scrapers. One way that works reliably for 4sysops is leveraging Cloudflare's Web Application Firewall (WAF). Cloudflare's free plan provides all the essential tools to safeguard your site against content theft by AI companies. However, I found that Cloudflare's new Block AI Scrapers and Crawlers feature is insufficient for the task. Fortunately, Cloudflare's WAF is sophisticated enough to reliably block all AI scrapers and other web parasites with a single, relatively simple rule. My proposed method serves as a way to enforce an opt-in approach, rather than relying on the non-binding opt-out recommendations in your robots.txt file.
articles.title: Block AI scrapers and other web parasites with Cloudflare

articles.author: odzhan
articles.description: Introduction Back in October 2018, I wanted to write ARM assembly on Windows. All I could acquire then was a Surface tablet running Windows RT that was released sometime in October 2012. Windows RT (now deprecated) was a version of ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí

articles.description:
This post explains an attack chain for the ChatGPT macOS application. Through prompt injection from untrusted data, attackers could insert long-term persistent spyware into ChatGPT‚Äôs memory. This led to continuous data exfiltration of any information the user typed or responses received by ChatGPT, including any future chat sessions.
 OpenAI released a fix for the macOS app last week. Ensure your app is updated to the latest version.
Let‚Äôs look at this spAIware in detail.
articles.title: Spyware Injection Into Your ChatGPT's Long-Term Memory (SpAIware)
